results.content:
Not only is this course comprehensive in its curriculum, it's easy to follow along in real time because Brett's cadence is easy to follow. There is a fair amount of repetition as you make your way through the course; however, that is a good thing. The classic adage, "Practice makes perfect" couldn't be truer when learning a programming language, development pattern, architecture or syntax, etc.

There are times that Brett goes silent while writing code. I wasn't able to tell whether or not he does so deliberately. In either case, when he does it is an opportune time to pause the video and give writing the next little bit of code in advance an attempt. (This is where the practice makes perfect comes in). I, myself, found that in the later parts of the course I wasn't watching the video as much as I was listening for the next task and writing all the code myself and not blindly mimicking the code in the video.

Overall, I am incredibly pleased with my purchase of this course and can't wait to use the new skills this course has given me and will be keeping an eye on any future courses Brett might build.

results.content:
The course project is very helpful because Ben demonstrates real-world development techniques you might not find in other courses, such as organizing your code into multiple project files, dependency injection, and unit tests. 

Other courses often have you make a single-project solution that, while ultimately showcasing the same functionality, do so in a way that skips patterns like creating services and dependency injection that doesn't prepare you as well for something you might find in a professional environment.

I've taken a couple of other ASP.NET MVC courses on Udemy before this, and I feel much more confident in my abilities for professional development after this one in particular!

results.content:
The introduction to C# is good for a newbie, sure. And for an experienced programmer, I can see that this can be a useful course to get some extra information on ASP NET.

BUT...for a newbie, the use of Visual Studio to learn about ASP NET MVC design is lacking in explanation. Too often lines of code are justified by vague statements like "this links up... to the controller", which is fine but the claim that a Newbie will become a Ninja is clearly not true. For example, I think the true test of this course is to ask a Newbie to take it, and then ask them to make a different web application afterwards with only occasional reference to the tutorials. It would be a hopeless task! 

Maybe this is due to a lack of exercises (coding along is not the same thing at all!), or maybe it is a lack of explanation of the code. For example, I am 85% of the way through the course and I cannot recall mention of what the @ symbol actually does, or the background of it, e.g. in @Url.Action... . Maybe it was mentioned once, but without proper explanation or exercises to learn about these things I cannot recall everything that was mentioned in passing! 

However, Brett seems like a good guy, and I don't mean this personally, I would hope he looks at some of the other tutors out there who maybe have more of a background in the teaching side of things(?), e.g. Colt Steele, and looks to improve the course, because for someone like me, trying to learn these things, spending my own money on the course, it is not really good that I have had to go and pay for some other courses to back up what I have learned here.

results.content:
Overall the experience was great, but This isn't a course for total newbies. On the last session the author blazes through a lot of important and complex code and patterns tha I had to stop the video and google about what he was doing to understand what was going on.

Aslo, I recommend always showing the most correct approach FIRST, and than comment on the WRONG approaches as trivia afterwards. Instead of creating the first classes and methods by copying and pasting   and then Show how to use inheritance/generics, I suggest you do the reverse approach. The brain of the newbie will stick to the first thing thaught, and it's hard for the brain to re-learn again. 

The point is: The brain should learn the right approach first, and reinforce it later by peeking at the wrong approach and why they are wrong, Instead of Learning wrong, un-learning wrong, and re-laearning right.

Since the course is targeted at the newbie crowd, it would be nice to write comments on the code as you are coding to teach this much treasured practice among programmers.

But, overall, In 2 weeks I went from being a dinossaur C programmer to a MVC ASp.NET "Newbie" capable of creatign simple pages, and I am confident I'll pick up on the trickier details/concepts as I go.

results.content:
This is another course which uses one project "Hello World" and main method to do everything - constant deletion of previous code and adding new stuff - it becomes a confusing mess of arrays, dictionaries, structs, classes, etc.

It would be better to create new project/s to demonstrate or explain new topics so that you could go back to the projects at a later time for revision.

I stopped this course after the LINQ lecture, due to the way it was presented as mentioned above. Not sure if it got any better after that. Quite disappointing overall for me because of this.

response.content: Hi Gerry - I’m sorry you have not been enjoying the course. The first few sections examine different aspects of development methodologies hence why they are created in simple projects. There is then an MVC hello world project that again teaches different aspects in a simple manner. However the final section brings everything together into a properly built enterprise e-commerce built as individual projects using the patterns learnt in the earlier lectures. If you feel you are already competent I highly advise skipping to that section.

results.content:
Makes changes to the project between lectures and doesn’t explain what changed; though you can download the changes;
                But if you’re supposed to be learning how to do this – then we should do the entire thing – not three parts out of five.
Only shows how to do EntityFramework with the INITIAL load, and modifying existing classes. Does not show how to add new classes.
 
Doesn’t think ahead in the class; but then says “Oh, we need to add another method” and then immediately pastes the completely finished new method, and clicks away to another screen before you’ve even had a chance to register that something just happened. So he typed it all up ahead of time – didn’t tell you anything about it, then just dropped it and walked away.
Never changes the front page – you always come up into the “ASP.Net is a free web framework for building….” – come on – if you’re going to teach building an eCommerce site – you should have at least enough polish to change the basic starter text on the front page.
 
I’m trying to LEARN the material – not get an overview of the material.
The instructor calls himself a “Professional Programmer and Teacher”; I disagree. I have learned some useful programming techniques from him, but he is *NOT* a professional teacher – he skips too much material, and makes changes on you in project structure without walking you through it – a professional teacher would not do this.
 
It appears that this recorded course was recorded on his dry-run; which he should have done ahead of time, to work out all of the bugs; and then re-recorded from scratch without incurring the numerous issues throughout the course, which he does in fact incur.

response.content:
Hi Kevin,

thank you for taking the time to write a review of my course.  

I would like to just answer a few points.

As a developer (actually I'm a solutions architect) I have to manage and interview developers who work in my company.  One of the things I find most frustrating is the lac of basic programming knowledge - most web developers know a bit of HTML and how to use the wizards to create basic pages and basically run through the standard tutorial scattered around the internet.

This is not being a programmer.  In my course I try to focus on how to BUILD a website that adheres to proper standards you normally only see in real development team (as apposed to self learned individual freelancers).

As the beginning of the course teaches the core of c# development I took the view that by the time we get into build a real website using industry standard patterns (such as Repository) the student would be proficient enough to not need to see me type boiler plate code.  I felt if would be more efficient to supply the code and then walk you through it - the majority being self explanatory if you've understood the basic lectures (such as how to create a new class).

Yes I do sometimes write code and then realise I need to add or update a method to make it work.  I spent some time discussing with other lecturers (and some students) about this and actually the consensus was to leave this as it was rather the re-record the lectures - the theory being is that this is EXACTLY how software development works in the real world!  i.e. you often have to skip around code to make other classes work.  I understand how this might not be everybody's cup of tea though.

For the home page - no I don't change it much - my course is about C# development using the MVC pattern - not how to write HTML - I'm often quite clear on this throughout the course as HTML is a big subject all on its own (in fact I have a separate course on HTML) - and I didn't want to spend time teach HTML when I assume my students have come to learn c#.

Finally, I would like to point out that as a student of Udemy help is always on hand through the forums - I regularly monitor them for questions and provide feedback.

So again, thank you for your review, and I am sorry if this course wasn't quite for you.

Regards

response.content:
Hi Uzoma,

I took the view that what was important was learning how to code - not watching me verbosely type everything out.  For this reason as the course progresses past the basics instead of you having to watch me type out boiler plate code, I thought it would be far more efficient to supply the code for you (all code used in my courses can be downloaded from the resources tabs) - and then walk you through pointing out the important bits that aren't self explanatory.  

Also, due to the nature of modern web development - i.e. that much of coding is now about plugging in other components from NuGET - it's difficult (some would say impossible) to ensure you're always bug free because if one of the libs you are using gets updated the original code may no longer work exactly the same.

In my course the common issues arise from a) Entity Framework getting updated - and the fix is to simply remove and re-add the libs from Nuget and b) That mixing your code with that which you download will create inconsistencies in Entity Framework.  Again the simple fix is to simply delete all migrations and the database and re add a new complete migration.

Over the past 12 months my course have been live these are the only reported 'bugs' and in both cases I have created videos showing step by step how to fix them.


Please also remember that part of being a student in Udemy means you get my help through the forums if you get into difficulty.

However thanks for taking your time to write a review and I wish you all the best success in the future.

Regards

results.content:
While this course is great, like introducing SOLID principles and some of the initial fundamental knowledge in MVC, it still has lack of quite some areas:

Navigation properties and how it's used in MVC
1-1 relationship and 1-Many relationship and how it's used in MVC when it come to CRUD operations

They are very essential knowledge in order to create real world application which this course has not really explored.

Additionally Repository Pattern used in this course is getting obsolete in newer version of EF and MVC so this course needs, as written on the ASP.Net: Writing additional code to implement these patterns is not always the best choice for applications that use EF, for several reasons:

The EF context class itself insulates your code from data-store-specific code.

The EF context class can act as a unit-of-work class for database updates that you do using EF.

Features introduced in Entity Framework 6 make it easier to implement TDD without writing repository code.

All in all, this course builds a strong basic foundation of MVC Web Development, it needs several more chapters to prepare you to be ready to develop some of the real world applications.

This course is defenetly not for beginners. I spent a lot of time doing research about concepts he is 'explaining' and the code that he's writting, and honestly, this is exactly why i didn't went for YouTube tutorials, because they are not fully comprehensive of all the details of what actually happens behind the scenes of the code to make you understand better how the language actually operates. This course is far average. Whatever he explains here and how it is explaining it, you can easily find on YouTube better explained and detailed

results.content:
The instructor, Brett, is very easy to understand in the lectures, in what is a very difficult subject (to someone with no prior experience in object oriented programming). Due to the object oriented nature of the MVC website there is a lot of going forwards and backwards between layers of the code, which can get confusing when the abstraction begins - I had to rewatch the lectures twice until it sunk in. The instructor explains at the start and throughout the course the reason for breaking up the code and using abstraction - to create a modular website that will not crash if you make a mistake in the code.
The instructor is prompt in replying to queries and has even updated the content when the situation merited it - including additional content on getting started with the database software that will be needed during the course, and a FAQ section at the end.

In short, an excellent course on what is a difficult subject, and an excellent instructor who is keen on maintaining the course content

results.content:
The course is good but I wouldn't call it 'Newbie' as in newbie developer. Maybe newbie to C# itself. Even as a fairly experienced developer in VB and SQL Server I found this difficult to understand in places. The presenter is obviously experienced and I understand that you can't create a whole eCommerce site using simple code only. However there was often use of complex built in functions and operators that were not explained properly and I cannot see how I would be able to know how to use these and what variables to put into them if I was to use them in the future and in different ways. These needed to be explained more clearly if possible. A lot was in the unit test presentation e.g. System.Web.Mvc.ControllerContext(httpContext, new System.Web.Routing.RouteData(), controller);

How ever there were a lot of built in inline functions in the view pages too that needed the different options explained and why the option that was being chosen was used. Partial views versus views also lost me a little.

results.content: For the most part, this course was really good. I learned a lot about how to properly structure my projects overall, which I didn't learn from my previous ASP.NET courses. HOWEVER, for anyone who is completely new to .NET, I would recommend taking both this course and another course. This course does not use proper formatting or naming conventions for typical .net code. In short, it is absolutely fantastic for learning how to program at the larger scale, but make sure you know what proper naming conventions look like as well. Because of the lack of conventions, some of the code is also a little harder to read, as there ends up being more redundant code (more else statements than necessary, more if statements than necessary, etc.).

results.content:
Lessons on DRY, DI and DI Container "Unity" (lessons 64, 65 and 66) are invaluable.

These lessons take you on a sweet tour of creating an abstract class for models to implement CRUD logic on generics,  coding to the interface to support DI and finally using Unity to configure the concrete classes for the DI.

I am withholding 0.5 star because the author did not leverage the Find() method in the Delete() and the Update() methods, instead duplicated the code already in the Find() method.

results.content:
The course is decent with some advanced and practical aspects touched such as related to interface usage, dependency injection, repositories, practical structure of app. However i believe that the OOPS concepts can be explained in more detail, and that the application created itself can be more detailed.  Also use of Ajax, Jquery etc. with Asp.net could have been tried in some examples.  
At some places the instructor can explain more in terms of the actual planning aspect of a particular component.  Such as for Basket etc.  Security Handling in a typical web application could probably also have been touched more (for example, what if one wishes to customise it).
I would call the course as OK but not comprehensive enough.

results.content:
After completing the course this is what I have to say about this course:
•	The pronunciation of the instructor is not understandable sometimes. Also, the voice of the instructor is so low in the videos.
•	English subtitles are not in sync with what the instructor is saying. The instructor says something else and subtitles are something different.
•	Some of the terms and topics are not well explained. You have to go through some other resources on the net to learn those things.
•	I think the connectivity from instructor to its audience is missing at some point.
•	Coding standards should be followed if you are targeting a large audience. I.e. MyClass, MyObject, MyLibrary names were used instead of this instructor could have used some meaningful names.
•	There is no exercise after each section to test your knowledge that whether you have understood the concepts completely or not. It would be great if the course had challenges section also.
•	Best practices are not followed. On the registration page, you can at least change the “FirstName” or “LastName” like labels using Display attribute. Yes, it was covered in the beginning but if we are building the real-world application then you must follow these rules also so the student can follow it.
•	How asp.net identity works internally is not explained. Yeah I know it’s a very vast topic but you can at least give some basic information for that. I had to learn those parts from other MVC course on Udemy.
•	And last but not the least, how can someone be “Newbie to Ninja” in Asp.Net MVC without learning Web API?

Though, it was good building the E-Commerce application.
Thanks.

Was originally very impressed with this course. The creator was clear and concise and explained things well. Sadly, in lectures 44 and on, he started adding code without explanations stating that they were just misc functions that the site wants, dont worry about it. His speed also picked up to be faster than I could follow along.

Now I feel as if I have wasted the days I sunk into the earlier lectures seeing as I cant proceed with how things are.

response.content:
Hi Kevin,
I'm sorry if you feel the pace picks up too much.  I'm always trying to balance going slow enough to give you the info you need, but not that slow you get bored!
As we progress through the course I took the decision that I could speed up as you learnt the basics.
I also start to supply some code rather than have you sat there watching me laborious type stuff, and again there are bits of code that are sometimes just boiler plate stuff and therefore shouldn't need to much explanation.

Of course this style doesn't always suit everyone.

However I would like to point out that we have the forums that are always very active - and many students learn a great deal from them - both by posting items they are struggling with and posts by others - programming is not the easiest subject in the world and when your coming to it from little experience getting involved in the forums/ community always helps.

Finally I always invite my students to message me directly with questions or requests for help - I am often requested to review code for my students and I do this happily.

So again apologies if the later lectures go to fast - but if you need help with anything please reach out via the forums or via message!

results.content:
Course style is very lecture based and does not offer much opportunity to apply your learning during the course to test and strengthen your knowledge. Concepts are covered in detail, but in most cases only once with little recapping during later examples, which would have been helpful to me. This course is good at covering the "how" to do things, but I found it to be light on the "why".

Although branded as suitable for beginners, I think it may be more suitable for those already familiar with C#, and who prefer to learn by watching/listening rather than doing.

results.content:
Sorry, there's too much teaching of the basic syntax of C# in a very slow pace, and the more advanced stuff about how to create mvc app are not focused enough and features some videos with terrible quality that prevent you to understand the written code.

I also didn't like that suddenly there are completely written classes during the creation of the mvc project, instead of creating them step by step.

Overall, I already knew the basics syntax of c# and OOP concepts , and unfortunately these are the only topics that are covered in good depth so I'm mainly disappointed.

response.content:
I'm sorry you feel Disappointed Yuval.  Ultimately this course is about trying to take someone from little or no knowledge to being proficient in building a site using ASP.NET MVC.

However I wanted to be different to all the other courses that just explain MVC and I wanted to explain how to build out solutions using projects - rather than having all the code in a single project that is then difficult to manage.

In order to achieve this I have to explain basic principles of OOP and SOLID - well done if you already understood all this - in my experience (and regularly have to interview new developers) this is actually rare in the web development world.

I also took the view that what was important was learning how to code - not watching me verbosely type everything out.

For this reason as the course progresses past the basics instead of you having to watch me type out boiler plate code, I thought it would be far more efficient to supply the code for you (all code used in my courses can be downloaded from the resources tabs) - and then walk you through pointing out the important bits that aren't self explanatory.

Please also remember that part of being a student in Udemy means you get my help through the forums if you get into difficulty.

Regards, and thanks for taking the time to write a review.

results.content: So I purshcased this course hoping to be able to build an ASP.NET MVC product and I came out learning a lot about ASP.NET MVC architecture and creation. However I found that my previous experience with Ruby on Rails didn't transfer very well to the ASP.Net framework. I knew it would be difficult but it turned out to be harder than I estimated and became easier to go back to what I know in Ruby on rails to create what I was looking for. However, as I stated, I learned a lot and ultimately learned that it wasn't for me. Had I spent more time trying to learn ASP.NET this course likely would have served as a great primer and I would have given it 4 or 5 stars. I didn't find any big problems with the course - things were explained well and in enough depth, they did take practice but the examples are well done and easy to follow along with. There is little to no style and look consideration given in this course however the course author knows that and it certainly doesn't detract from the goals of the course.

results.content:
The instructor tries to go from absolute never-wrote-code to advanced abstraction, interfaces, modules, etc... It feels a little fluffy in between. If you never coded before and would like a nice sweeping overview of MVC, C# and programming in general, it could help... but you'll need a lot of other courses to fill in gaping holes. It's far from "complete" despite trying perhaps TOO hard to cover every base.

There's also a heavy reliance on source code you download for each section. You're expected to download the code and watch the instructor graze vaguely over his own changes, not mentioning a lot of them and implementing even fewer yourself. To top it off, the source code kept breaking my database and I had to jump through hoops to use it.

Lastly, although he makes a good point at the end that he doesn't feel this course should dive into "design", what you're left with is not remotely polished even from a back end stance. Simple little things like neglecting to implement a "delete" link that keeps looming in your basket, or leaving "Application name" in the nav bar. C'mon, these things take minutes to fix.

That said, he does cover some really useful "best practices"

results.content: I'm a beginner programmer with some background in html and css, as well as c# for simple game development (Unity3D).  The first half of this class was very simple, and went over the basics of C# well for a complete newbie, which is good, but is already stuff I knew.  The SOLID stuff and discussion of abstraction and polymorphism is good as well, but I feel like simpler, more well-fleshed out examples would help a lot.  Once we got into the actual MVC stuff, however, I felt lost pretty quickly.  I understand databases fairly well (I work with MSSQL on a daily basis) but the actual mechanics behind the website construction was difficult to follow and felt rushed.  I understand the concepts (I think), but after this class I feel in no way ready to go and build something of my own.  More focus on MVC, why the projects are built the way they are, and the underlying mechanics would really help flesh this class out more.  I may revisit this class after taking a few others, and it's good to just see it done and be exposed to it, but I don't think I'm anywhere close to a "ninja" after this class.  Instructor could stand to take it slower and be much more thorough.  All in all, I think the first half of this class is great if you want to learn basic C#, and the second half if you are already understand MVC but want to refine the process of developing sites.

results.content:
Like others have said, the course material is outstanding through the C# primer, but the MVC portion often goes well beyond what a beginner will understand or find particularly useful. At a certain point I gave up on listening to what the instructor was trying to convey and just started copying code, which was difficult in and of itself due to a heap of syntax errors throughout the course, and a lack of explanation as to what was going in those situations; in a number of areas the instructor would actually stop talking altogether in order to go back and fix those errors. There were several times I looked away while this was happening, which resulted in a dig through 15+ minute videos to find out exactly where I made a mistake.

With all that being said, the course itself is an absolute gold mine of information relating to C# and ASP.NET MVC 5, and if you have the patience and experience required I highly recommend purchasing this course, even if only as a reference.

results.content: I found this course to be quite useful. Even though the course does not cover the plethora of different implementations and technologies that are available to MVC I believe it lives to true to what it intends to deliver; allows a relatively new programmer to grasp the concept of MVC and create a functional web app that they can use as a fantastic basis for introducing further concepts. I would like to just add that there seem to be a lot of comments about this course complaining that between each section there is code added by Brett with no explanation. This is not true at all, Brett saves us from having to watch him type copious amounts of code and always offers to complete solution to download at the start of each section and then spends to first part of the section explaining what has been added. Part of the learning experience is going through the newly added code and trying to understand what it does... Google is your friend!

results.content: This is not really a 'Complete' course in ASP.NET MVC for newcomers that takes them to expert levels. It is certainly a useful course but It would be more accurate to say this is a course for those somewhat familiar with MVC and Entity Framework who are newbies to structuring their MVC applications using application layering techniques via separate projects and adhering to SOLID principles. Udemy staff and content authors really should stop abusing the words Complete (and Ultimate as in some other courses) in order to cast as wide a net as possible to catch customers of all experience levels, only for customers to discover insufficient  and detailed explanations to justify this claim of complete coverage.

results.content:
Woah! Just finished....

I wouldn't recommend this for a 100% complete newbie - go take an in depth C# or two, along with a few other more simple .NET tutorials... AND THEN COME BACK TO THIS!

This course was super useful! It reinforced the basics, while showing a few more complex topics such as the repository pattern, uploading files, and building out the whole basket was super helpful. I was afraid this might be just repeating the same old info as other "basic" tutorials, but this really added to my knowledge set - stuff that the other tutorials didn't have!

The instructor did a great job explaining the content. Good pace. I see his GitHub repo has a few more branches that he worked on, so hopefully he adds those videos soon too.

I HIGHLY recommend this course after you're semi-familiar with C# & .NET, this really adds a lot compared with other tutorials.

results.content: Video quality is horrible (only 720). Audio quality equally bad. Sounds like Brett is sitting in a metal box, and the volume is really low. This is why I stopped buying courses on Udemy. Seems like they don't vet anything, they just want to add content. I've seen free YouTube videos that are better. I'd like to make comments on the actual content but I literally stopped watching after lecture 6. I could not take it any more. Wish I had not waited so long after purchasing to make the time to start watching it because now I can't request a refund.
